Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied warranty of habitability and a covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This concurrence/dissent agrees that Massachusetts should abandon caveat emptor and recognize an implied obligation regarding the habitability of residential units, but it disputes the majority’s chosen doctrinal label (“implied warranty of habitability”) and scope. The author instead would ground the obligation in an implied covenant to comply with statutory and code-based minimum standards and make that obligation mutually interdependent with the tenant’s duty to pay rent. The excerpt does not discuss the separate covenant of quiet enjoyment, and it comes from a separate opinion, but it does support the existence of an implied habitability obligation in residential tenancies under Massachusetts law.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tentant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious and substantial interference with her tenancy caused by the landlord or persons acting under the landlord’s control. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–03 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly explains the meaning and scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, describing it as protecting a tenant from serious interferences with tenancy and discussing liability where the landlord’s conduct, rather than intent, results in such interference. It also rejects the landlord’s argument that it cannot be held responsible for flooding caused in part by third parties, emphasizing the landlord’s duty to prevent such conditions and affirming liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for interference with quiet enjoyment. This squarely supports the proposition that the covenant protects tenants from serious and substantial interference caused by the landlord or those under its control.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … As its third objection to Solomon’s recovery on her count for interference with quiet enjoyment, Gem asserts that it was wrongly held responsible for the actions of third parties beyond its control. … The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent.”}

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from serious interference with their tenancy and analyzes landlord liability based on what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, including omissions regarding persons on the property. It further holds that if the landlord fails to take measures within its control to remove unwanted persons whose presence seriously interferes with tenants’ use, it may be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant protects against serious and substantial interference caused by the landlord or persons under its control.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … if the defendant has failed to take any measures…to remove unwelcome persons…then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct defective conditions in a timely and reasonable manner, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, even where the landlord did not act with malice. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–04; Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–90 (1994).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that civil liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 does not require malicious or reckless conduct, and that negligent failure to repair known defects that foreseeably and substantially impair the premises can constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court applies this to Cruz Management’s failure to correct serious code violations after notice and finds a § 14 breach, explicitly rejecting the trial judge’s view that recklessness was required. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s untimely and unreasonable failure to correct defects after notice can breach § 14 even without malice.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “We concluded in the Solomon case, with respect to civil liability, that ‘malicious intent is not necessary, and that the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct’… These statements are not incompatible with the imposition of liability based on negligence… A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14… Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord is strictly liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for violations of a tenant’s quiet enjoyment that result from the landlord’s acts or failures to act, including the landlord’s failure to take reasonable steps to correct code violations or defective conditions. See Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 790–91; Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that the landlords’ failure to provide heat—required by the State Sanitary Code—constituted a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that the landlords’ financial inability to purchase oil was not a defense. The court emphasizes that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct and the natural and probable consequences, not intent, thereby imposing a form of strict liability for failures to act (here, failure to furnish heat/code compliance) that interfere with quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “The tenant correctly argues that the judge erred in declaring that the landlords’ financial inability to purchase oil constituted a defense to the quiet enjoyment claim. A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not specifically discuss heating defects, but it squarely holds that a landlord’s failure, after notice, to repair substantial defects that interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment constitutes a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14. The Court emphasizes that liability under the quiet enjoyment statute commonly arises from a landlord’s negligent failure to cure known defects and cites multiple examples (flooding, leaky roof, habitability issues). Thus, while not about heating in particular, it supports the broader proposition that persistent, uncorrected, substantial defects can breach quiet enjoyment.

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 403\u.proposition: Where a landlord violates G.L. c. 186, § 14, the statute mandates an award of "actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater," plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. at 285; Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 403–04 (1982).
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 403\u.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explains that the statute allows tenants to recover "actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater." The court applies this to uphold a three-months-rent award under § 14 and discusses its purpose, confirming that triple rent is mandatory where it exceeds actual and consequential damages. Although this case does not itself discuss costs and attorney’s fees, it clearly supports the damages portion of the quoted proposition.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 403\u.relevant_excerpt: The judge awarded $990 (three months’ rent) to the tenants on a finding that the landlord had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14, the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. General Laws c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, allows tenants to recover “actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater,” for violation of that statute.
